A bizarre trip into both a child's imagination and the Spanish Civil War in the midst of World War II, "Pan's Labyrinth" feels like a brutal and imaginative deconstruction of fairy tale fantasies like Narnia, tapping into the terror of those fantasy's pagan roots and violent context both. The character of the Captain is terrifying, and Ofelia is marvelously played and terribly sympathizing. Balancing complex themes, and wisely spending most of its time in the real world setting of Spain in an under-explored slice of history, del Toro really goes for the jugular on this one, literally and metaphorically. The brutal edge of this film could have been toned back some (del Toro does a good enough job of building dread that he could afford to pull back occasionally) but the story is surprisingly affecting. A fascinating exploration of a child's imaginative perspective interacting with the horrible evil of the real world.

Guillermo del Toro's wild fascination with practical creatures, locations and effects is often more impressive than the often acclaimed tendencies of auteur director Christopher Nolan, a man famed for his attempts to make the unrealistic possible. Del Toro understands that a magnificent and rich visual palette can very much accent the story and characters of a film, and that the technical wizardry behind cinema is often more important the screenwriter who pens the picture. Pan's Labyrinth is perhaps Del Toro's finest folio of work in regards to his aesthetic competence, his ability to be able to accent dialogue, action and brutality with movement, colour, framing and practical effects absolutely applaudable.

Though that's not to discount the capacity of Del Toro's writing ability, his ability to be able to bring to a life a story that encapsulates a combination of wonder and intrigue with pain and hardship never so utterly palpable as it is here. Pan's Labyrinth tells the story of a young girl, Ofelia, who escapes the horrors and misery of her literal life by fleeing to the depths of her imagination, and bringing into existence stories of fanciful creatures and magical lands. When she is brought by her pregnant mother to a military outpost manned by her new, sadistic stepfather, she becomes convinced that she is a long lost princess, lost to her underground homeland after she walked into the sunlight of the surface and was relieved of her memories. She is brought into a labyrinth that presides close to the outpost by a fairy, who helps her uncover a Faun who seeks to bring her back into her rightful kingdom. All this transpires whilst Ofelia's stepfather is attempting to quell a rebellion provoked by republicans who detest the current Francisco Franco regime and wish for it change.

Del Toro weaves the two interconnecting stories of war and fantasy together with immense precision and delicacy. He seeks to provide both components of the story their moments in the sun, and when the war and fanciful elements combine, truly spectacular moments materialize. The fairy tale-like pacing, characters and plot, which feature relatively simplistic constructs that are surrounded by more intricate details, feels old-timely, and so fans of old-school cinema should appreciate the workmanship on offer here. Perhaps the only detractor from the film as a whole is its imbalance in terms of how much of the mythological portion of the picture is shown; whilst one who has seen the trailer and theatrical posters would be willing to contend that the film seems to feature more of the fairy tale story than the one that occurs in the modern reality, you would in fact be incorrect. This is a minor but key drawback, as these fanciful sequences are absolutely the most engaging segments of the picture, and their slim quantity, whilst leaving us desiring more (which is better than oversaturation), proves frustrating and partially disappointing. That said, the fantasy sequences are by far the most memorable and where Del Toro's plethora of knowledge and skill come to the forefront.

This isn't to discount the story that is occurring in the reality of Ofelia's situation. Her stepfather, the military Captain Vidal, is without concern for his new daughter, and abuses her both physically and mentally without restraint at certain points. Unlike Ofelia's mother, the kind hearted and passionate Carmen, he is not afraid to display his shame for his stepdaughter for all to see. And whilst he is not entirely morally ambiguous, his lack of sensitivity, sympathy or empathy proves alienating for both our protagonist and ourselves. He is the perfect antagonist; someone of reasonable intellect, but with dastardly intentions and lacking in warmth. The largest subplot of the film features his search for the rebels of Spain who are against the current government, but the specifics of this story are never fully realised or placed in the forefront. Continuing on in the classic fairy tale fashion, Del Toro disregards such trivial details and instead focuses on something far more emotionally poignant; stories of survival and love, betrayal and deception. The handmaiden for Ofelia and her mother, Mercedes, is working with the rebels, and she possesses an infatuation with one of the soldiers who she is meant to be against. She works alongside Ferreiro, a doctor who works as an informant but nevertheless provides aid to Carmen as she enters the late stages of her pregnancy. Their plight is nearly as compelling as Ofelia's journey into the depths of her wild creativity.

Del Toro has never been seen as this lavish and complex, his story somehow managing to entwine two different, contrasting stories with ease. He brings the flourishing nature of the fairy tale sequences into the war conflicts, which feature large and bountiful sets representing the muddled mental state many of the main and supporting characters contain. Captain Vidal is the perfect example of this, his room being comprised of bold circular establishments that feel thrown together in an assortment of forms that prove cluttered and messy. His deteriorating mental state is reflected by this shambled set, meticulously constructed with attention to detail that allows close examination. Del Toro's ability to be able to extract information about any individual, their personality and their stance through visual story telling, whether it be through the gorgeous cinematography (which rightfully won an Academy Award), the set design, the lighting, the costume design or the magnificent make-up (which also was awarded top honours at the aforementioned ceremony), is utterly worthy of praise. Whereas so many directors limit their visual appeal and revert to basic and unimaginative dialogue sequences to indulge the audience in information, Del Toro understands that to quicken his pace and maintain the attention of the audience he needs to take full advantage of the format which he is constructing for; this isn't a book which is conceived with words. This is a work of moving images and sound, and Del Toro uses both those contexts to their fullest being.

Del Toro's cinematography in particular deserves great admiration, and whilst I briefly touched upon its brilliance, it deserves a more detailed examination. Guillermo Navarro's work in all of his collaborations with Del Toro has been viewed as spectacular, from their original pairing for Cronos to 2013's exceptionally good-looking Pacific Rim, but none can best Pan's Labyrinth in sheer passion and beauty. The way Navarro moves his cameras is spectacular, and he always seeks invigorating and challenging ways to engage the audience in less striking sequences (the way he frames two characters together and has them move and waver whilst in discussion is particularly fantastic). Navarro and Del Toro are also huge fans of the "reveal" shot; this is where the camera is circling a character from one angle to eventually, for a sudden and shocking effect, reveal a character or group of characters that either pop into frame or appear at another angle that may be considered a threat. This shot is most prominent in the fantasy sequences and they are entrancing, beautiful pieces of cinematography, namely this one at 0:44 minutes in, which pans to reveal a creature which we are initially unsure of and consider a potential danger to our protagonist. It's visually pleasing to see a director who wants his camera to be involved with the characters, their revelations, discoveries and shocks. The men never complicate their frames too much to the extent of, say, a Michael Bay picture, which contains so many moving and contrasting points of depth that the frame is immensely difficult to comprehend, but they still manage to possess an extensive preoccupation with size, movement and visual storytelling. For fans of lush and gorgeous cinematography and blocking, there are few films which are as admirable as Pan's Labyrinth.

The texture of the film, accented with often dark and muddy lighting (as well as my favourite feature of cinema: rain!) provides yet more personality and darkness to this confounding tale of innocence lost. These are juxtaposed with gorgeous and intimate golds as well as relaxing purples and dark blues. The former can be seen here, and the latter within the formerly mentioned clip a paragraph upwards. David Lee and Ricardo Rodríguez, the two gaffers responsible for the lighting design are very much worthy of commendation, their work on this film utterly fantastic; even preferable to Lee's work within Hellboy II, another quality Del Toro feature that benefits greatly from Lee's contributions. Also amiable is the score, composed by Javier Navarette, which doesn't necessarily contain that many individual stand out moments, but contains a multitude of thematic concepts which work together to form narrative constructs in the musical realm. Navarette utilizes deep gothic flavours, Spanish-themed instrumentation and light choral influences to compose a harrowing and beautiful score that works wonders both inside and outside of its intended context. An exceptionally powerful work (you can read more acclaim here).

There honestly isn't much to complain about. Ofelia's story is handled with sincerity but a childlike naivety that is slowly torn away as her ignorance and credulity is slowly washed away to reveal a tender and young soul. Del Toro presents a classic story with modern features and gorgeous, sweeping cinematography, to provide nearly two hours of absolute euphoria. It is faulted slightly in its balance between the two differentiating storylines, but this sole detractor isn't worth enough to render anything less than a near-perfect rating. Every second of Pan's Labyrinth is full of rich beauty, imagination, wild creativity and detail. This is an emotional, carefully constructed, but ultimately ingenious creation that renders a thoroughly heartbreaking experience that shan't be forgotten soon. A great way to heighten my anticipation for Del Toro's next picture, Crimson Peak. Highly recommended.

I put off watching this film for a long time. I am so glad that I finally watched it. Honestly, if I'd known what I was missing out on, I would have watched it a long time ago. 

Pan's Labyrinth begins with a strange, confronting scene as blood bactracks through a small girl's nose as she lies on the ground. We are then told of an ancient fairy tale, in which a princess escapes from her underground kingdom to the world above where he dies, leaving her spirit to return in a different form at a later time. 

In another story strand, we find Ofelia, the young girl who we saw bleeding at the beginning on her way to see her stepfather. It is towards the end of the Spanish civil war. 

These two scenarios, though polar opposites, somehow go side by side perfectly as we follow the dastardly gentleman Captain Vidal and his seemingly-delusional step-daughter. 

At first it seems that the film will be about the Captain and his effect on Ofelia. That's up until we meet the faun. The introduction of Pan takes the whole film to an entirely new level, combining an incredibly beautiful fantasy world with an almost as darkly beautiful soldier's camp. The art direction is amazing. Whether it's Pan's inverted knees and knotted shoulders or a gigantic toad or intensely gruesome moments of violence, it's incredible. The intense detail is astounding as well, especially in one outstanding sequence with an extremely disturbing creature known as the pale man. The table of food practically glistens while the walls are covered in beautifully vile images of his escapades. 

The script is great too. We experience just how wrapped up in her fantasies Ofelia is and just how cold Captain Vidal can be, as well as just how desparate Carmen is. The delivery by the actors is nothing short of brilliant, with standout performances by Sergi Lopez as Vidal and Doug Jones as Pan and the Pale Man. Jones' performance is especially powerful delivering scolding speeches with incredible power. Del Toro also coaxes an incredible performance from his diminutive lead, Ivana Baquero. She brings an authenticity to a role which could have easily been made into a caricature with the whole wide eyes and high voice routine. A lot of credit for that goes to the script which doesn't treat its child star like a child. 

The score is a beautiful, with the constant of a Spanish lullaby which helps to purport the difficulty in sorting the reality from fantasy. 

Del Toro's work in this film is something to be praised, seeing as the Hellboy's weren't really anything to be in awe of. But he creates his own style in this film, with seamless transtitions from one shot to the next and beautifully choreographed camera movement. 

Pan's Labyrinth is a brilliant film with frightening intensity and a truly original take upon fantasy as well as bringing a feeling of danger in the face of the fantasy, much akin to Where the Wild Things Are. With a brilliant ending which causes a collision with fantasy and reality as well as causing a crazy headspin to the viewers, Pan's Labyrinth is definitely worth watching multiple times.

Pan's Labyrinth is a film that is quite abundant in magic, but in a dark and suitably mature context. You could compare it to Alice in Wonderland in terms of surreality, but in my opinion, this film is what Alice in Wonderland would be like if it were rooted in a deathly serious tone. The plot alternates between the alluring fantasy of the labyrinth, and the grim reality of Francoist Spain. Until the very end of the film, both worlds seem equally dark, and this film does very well to try and juggle the two worlds together. Aside from the beautifully dark visuals, the film's biggest strength, perhaps, is its ability to establish a sense of mood, and this makes it easy for the viewer to believe that the film is going a certain way. For example, the final scenes of the film had me believing that the film was a bitter ending (which I actually would have welcomed), so the relatively positive ending came as quite a surprise. The performances helped the film's overall mood significantly, and I find that it was very easy for me to engage with the characters, although I find that many of the real world characters were unlikable, which I think may have been intended by the writers to establish the real world as a truly horrible place. It presents a vision of fantasy wrapped in horror and drama, yet with a light at the end of the tunnel. It's a very intriguing and artistic adventure filled with real emotion, and that by itself more than worth watching.

At long last, my dark-in-all-the-right-places fairy tale is here! Pan's Labyrinth tells two stories in one movie. Ofelia (Ivana Baquero) is a young girl who lost her father and is moving with her mother to a temporary Spanish army base. The mother (Ariadna Gil) plans to wed the captain (Sergi Lopez), and is pregnant with his child, whom the captain strongly believes will be a son. From here is when the story splits. Ofelia loves fairy tales, and in this time of desire to escape from reality, she discovers the realm of magic and an opportunity for her to lead a new life as princess of the Underworld. Guiding her is the deliciously deceitful faun named Pan (Doug Jones), whose labyrinth holds the portal awaiting to be opened. Her side of the story is a fantastical, sometimes frightening, adventure. Her primary obstacle is reality. Is the adventure a dream or not? That's up to you. Meanwhile, in seemingly unrelated news, a republican rebel force has formed to take back the power that the nationalist army ripped from the rebels during the Spanish civil war (which I knew very little about, going into the movie). This war section isn't just some given circumstance. Roughly half of the movie pays attention to the battle between the two sides. My primary question, after the movie had ended, was, "Why were these two stories told as one?" It took some time to think about it. Eventually, I connected the fantasy and reality by observing that, at the beginning, both Ofelia and the rebels are in a place of despair. They can only cope with their surroundings and circumstances by ambitiously following a dream that seems impossible to realize in reality. Pan's Labyrinth ends in serenity, masked by bloody destruction. The more I think about the story as a whole, the more I love it.

I refer to Pan's Labyrinth as a fairytale, and I also said that it is dark in all the right places. I'll bring to your attention that the film is R-rated, and it gets very messy in some places. A large, gluttonous frog once vomits out his whole body, while the captain once stabs a local's face to death with a baton. That's something to keep in mind. I'm not sure how I feel about the captain. Some may write him off as a stereotypically evil military buff. I felt the same way until his love for his child becomes a driving force. He's more in love with his legacy than the child itself, but the child nevertheless adds depth to the captain's character. Right on, Sergi Lopez. Ivana Baquero is a very competent child actress, unconcerned about acting like a child. Her courage and thrill for adventure far outshines her occasionally naive, childlike actions. And she never goes for the melodramatic, even in the most traumatic moments. My favourite actor is Doug Jones, who plays both Pan and the Pale Man, a child devourer with eyes on his hands. The physicality he gives to both characters gives me chills, perhaps too in debt to the choice cinematography and lighting. Scenes at night are only illuminated by the moon, and scenes indoors purposely have dull colouring. My guess is that director Del Toro did not want the film to look like a vivid Disney film. It's all so mystical, and I love it. I swam back and forth from reality to fantasy, and I would do it again.

Pan's Labyrinth, regarded by many as Guillermo del Toro's masterpiece and arguably regarded as one of the best films of the decade. I have seen this film twice and I never could grasp the power that everyone seems to receive from watching this film, but I am able to clutch on to a few things that this film does right.

The film is an original screenplay written by Guillermo del Toro, he mostly participates in the film's writing when he directs a film, and what he has crafted here is definitely something that is personal to him. Del Toro has written a story set in a time where the land of Spain was in a state of war within itself; the characters in this story, particularly the protagonist Ofelia, is searching for a land in order to gain peace and wipe away the horrors of reality. The film was able to establish the connection that Ofelia has with this magical world at the start, allowing us to believe and understand the connection she has with this fantasy. The tasks that Ofelia must go through seem to represent subtly a virtue that she must gain in order to become a better person, or for her sake a 'princess', which is important to have in a world that she currently lives in and the world she aspires to join in. Del Toro lets the audience follow two storylines, Ofelia's and the Spanish rebels, in a way they both connect but each one can be made into a film of it's own. The characters in this film are great to watch, with Ofelia being so driven in her goal to find her way back home and Vidal being so ruthless that my eyes widen whenever he has plans to inflict pain. The faun was interesting to see as he is a creature that is, to my knowledge, never been seen in cinema. The dialogue in this film, for the most part, works but there are a few times where it needed a little more substance but this is just a minor issue.

This film, is my starting point in del Toro's filmography. Pan's Labyrinth is a film that contains Fantasy elements that have been found on films like Alice In Wonderland and The Wizard of Oz but employs a much darker tone. Del Toro made this film to feel accessible to adults as he doesn't allow the story to be sugar coated in order to sell Ofelia's story. Del Toro has been known to incorporate horror in his films, and he does so here but not just for the sake of having it. The horror comes from the pain that these characters suffer and it allows the audience to feel their pain, regardless of who is the victim. It is supported by not holding back on the use of blood and violence, allowing the film to create a stronger effect on us. The film's pacing works, especially towards the climax, as he cuts back and forth to the war in reality and Ofelia's journey. My main issue with the film is that the film leans towards more on the reality side, with the fantasy aspect of it feeling underwhelming and unexplored. I wanted more from this magical world in order for me to care in Ofelia succeeding, it doesn't have to go to such lengths in dedicating a long scene for it to be explored but it could have been included in the dialogue between the faun and Ofelia.

The film's cinematography was handled by Guillermo Navarro, who is a frequent collaborator with del Toro. The earliest film I have seen of Navarro's work is Jackie Brown, which was darker than Quentin Tarantino's previous films; that style in creating that dark atmosphere is found here. Navarro's photography is one of the main reasons why del Toro's film feels very mature. This allows us to take the film's story seriously and understand that this is more than just a children's fantasy film. Never throughout the film does it look natural. Navarro handles the film's night/dark scenes to look cold with a blue palette, while he exhibits the daytime sequences to feel very warm. The camera captures what it needs to establish the scene and support the ideas that del Toro wants the scenes to project. I hope this collaboration keeps on going in future films as both seem to have a great understanding of each other's intentions. 

The film's score was handled by Javier Navarrete who has worked with del Toro previously on The Devil's Backbone and Cronos. His score here doesn't draw attention to itself, but rather subtly emerges in order to sell a scene or to avoid the scene from feeling still. The only time when Navarrete's score stands out is when it uses the lullaby in the film, as it stays with you throughout and even when it ends. The score didn't sound too melodramatic or did it feel too cliche'd but it definitely didn't show that it was a force to be reckon with.

Ivana Baquero plays the film's protagonist. She played the part well but it never got to a point where I was amazed or inspired by her work, Baquero just performed what was required in order to come off as tolerable. Sergi Lopez on the other hand was a standout, maybe it also is due to how well written his role is. Lopez succeeds to come off as ruthless and threatening without having to be so obvious to us on how 'evil' this guy really is. Which is the reason why his moments of violence comes off as a shock rather than just something that is expected. Maribel Verdu did her part well as Mercedes. She was able to play off as an 'inside man' character while also be a caring older sister for Ofelia. Doug Jones as Pan (Faun) was a delight to watch as he was able to project himself as someone who is bizarre but also frightening.

My opinion of Pan's Labyrinth may be in the minority but I cannot say that this film is not worth a watch as it has the ability to create a bridge between reality and fantasy and coming off it satisfied with what Guillermo del Toro has crafted for us.

Nobody ever seems to understand that the original fairytales (such as Sleeping Beauty and the Little Mermaid) were all very dark tales in the beginning, before Disney and the like changed them. This movie is like a classic (a real classic) fairytale. The designs, the story, the places, the people; everything reminds me of a classic fairytale! And it's all fantastic. I won't act like it's the most perfect movie ever (I am of the belief that nothing is ever perfect, but things can be so close that any flaws something has doesn't matter and are inconsequential overall), but this is extremely good, even with the slight flaws I did finally notice upon a second viewing. Nothing major or terrible enough to draw away from the film. I was hooked from the start, because I felt like a little kid again, but instead of going on a fluffy kid friendly adventure, I was instead going on an adult adventure. That doesn't happen very often. I'm not saying this movie is good for kids, but it's good for people who relished being treated as adults in film as a kid. For some reason it just struck me as something like that. And what's more, instead of other films that ram symbolism down the audiences collective throats, this one just didn't seem to do that. Yes it has symbolism, but even if you somehow took that away from it, it would still stand on its own. That is the art of good film making. And the acting; what else can I say that others already haven't? Doug Jones is just fantastic, top notch! With other actors, if they had to wear all that makeup and other things to look like Pan, they would just seem so wooden and stilted, or you would see the actor playing the creature, not the creature itself. But with Doug, I never got that sense. It was Pan on my screen. It was the Pale Man on my screen. No one else. Everyone else is wonderful in their own roles as well, it's just that Doug overshadowed them terribly with his performance. But that's okay, because they all still did a great job. I can't help but sympathize with Ophelia (what a pretty name by the way) since I grew up in a single parent household. When Ophelia and her mother are having that conversation about why her mother remarried, I saw me and my mother talking instead, because I had that same conversation with my mother so many times at that age. I couldn't understand what she meant about being alone, but now I do. So I could really appreciate the realism of that scene. It's been so long since I saw a movie capture my attention and imagination like this one did. In fact, it's been a while since I've actually felt grateful for being able to watch a movie. I don't think I've felt that way since the Avengers. And that's the best thing I can say for this film: it made me proud that there can still be good films made post-2000. If you listen to anybody else it doesn't seem that way, but this film is a good reminder that not every film that can be made has already been made yet. I'm glad I watched it and I will definitely watch it again sometime soon.

Many of the world's most ancient myths and fairy tales are notoriously bloody affairs, perhaps because they date from times when death seemed to strike so capriciously. The 20th century, too, was at times brutally and indiscriminately violent, thanks in no small part to the fascist regimes of 1930s and 1940s Europe. Guillermo del Toro sets these two legacies of violence side by side at a Franco-era Spanish military compound built atop a stone ruin and surrounded by woods. This is the killing ground of a fascist officer, but it is also the home (really the prison) of his stepdaughter Ofelia, a book-loving girl who sees monstrous creatures in the trees and walls. Ofelia's encounters with a faun, insectoid fairies, and a faceless, child-killing thing with blood-stained claws are the most creative and interesting parts of the movie. It is unfortunate that so much time is spent away from her and these CG creations and spent instead on her stepfather, who feels like a villain imported from a slasher horror. His persecution of a band of clichéd guerrillas is predictable, and more gruesome than seems necessary for a fantasy period piece. At last, though, del Toro provides an ending that feels true to both the fairytale world and the real one, without compromising the dark tone he sets for both.

Pan's Labyrinth is one of those films that starts so well that you hope it will stay that good but which actually surprises you and constantly improves. It's a remarkably layered work about the importance of choice even in an emotional and political dictatorship and about the fictions and fantasies that sustain people through the worst circumstances. On the surface this appears to be little more than a more fantastic spin on The Spirit of the Beehive, sharing its post-Spanish Civil War setting as well as the broken family setting, but this is a far superior film in every way. Although marketed largely as a fantasy, its real power lies in the scenes set in the real world where Sergi Lopez's all too believable Fascist monster is mopping up the few remaining communist guerrillas in the hills while waiting for his sick wife to give birth to his son while her daughter from her first marriage tries to reassert her own identity rather than submit to the Captain's idea of family.

The challenges of the mythical world are far less disturbing - or violent - than the real one, and it's all too easy to see why she wants to escape into the darkness of the labyrinth where at least the hope of something better exists. But then she's not the only one escaping into the imagination, as her mother sustains herself with a romanticised view of her meeting the captain that he has no interest in whatsoever. To him stories - even a part of his family history that has passed into local legend - exist only to be denied. Lopez's greatest sin isn't the pride that he admits to, or even that he is so pitiless, it's that he chooses to obey without question: the girl's small triumph is that she does not. And the triumphs in the film are generally small, quiet ones, where courage and fear go hand in hand, making the few acts of decency all the more important when they occur. There is one "saved by the cavalry" moment that at first doesn't convince but does prove to be there for a definite purpose that makes the ending all the more powerful.

But while there's a lot going on underneath the surface of the film, it doesn't crush it with the weight of its ideas. It's directed with a visual assurance and, at times, playfulness that sweeps you along, sometimes with delight, sometimes with apprehension, but never simply for the sake of a nice shot or a neat special effect (most of which are incredibly well integrated for such a low budget feature). The performances are superb, with Lopez somehow managing to avoid turning his irredeemable character into a caricature: this is an evil without conscience that is all too recognisable. Javier Navarette's beautiful score is also adept at walking the fine line between magic and emotion without crossing the line into schmaltz.

In a post civil-war Spain, the stepdaughter of a Fascist captain, who believes in killing every single one of the rebels of Franco's regime, find out she may be the princess of some distant magical world, and must go through tasks to claim her noble title. It's interesting to see what would usually be considered as a storyline for a younger audience get such a mature and violent on-screen rendition. Del Toro's stellar graphic production also finds added appeal with its remarkable graphics and creative art direction as well as some exciting special effects which darkly contrast the tenderness brought to the table by the child central character. Despite a somewhat slow start, Pan's Labyrinth is an adventurous and scary vision which seeks to and succeeds in re-inventing the genre.

Most critics say Pan's Labyrinth is a wondrous fairy tale, a beautifully crafted film with a awe inspiring story and amazing fantasy elements that will surely be some of the best ever seen. Other critics say it was amazing, a movie like no other with a surefire way to win your emotions and love for this film. Some critics say it is the best film of the decade, others of all time. I think I saw the wrong Pan's Labyrinth. Guillermo del Toro's "classic" film is not what I thought it would be. In my opinion, it is not a fairy tale, but a drama film with fairy tale elements. We barely get much fantasy in this movie anyway, as we are stuck in the world of mortals most of the films, and we don't experience much fantasy feel within the film. But when there is fantasy, fairy tale like moments in the film, it is done right. It is done amazingly. The entire movie, you see a little more fantasy, and what you do see you beg for more of it. The puppetry in this movie is fantastic, and so is the CGI. The faun in this movie looks so good I just wanted to see more of him. We also see bugs that turn into fairies, and a hand-eyes monster that creeps down your spine. It's a strange film, but one that will amaze you with it's puppetry and CGI. But we just don't get enough of that amazement. Sure, it gives us a decent story to put that fairy tale back drop on, but that story is in no way as compelling as the characters themselves. We just need more of the "fairy" aspect of this fairy tale, not more of the mortal, human world story. Strangely, Guillermo del Toro pulls the same kind of trick in Pacific Rim. We get plenty of human characters and their lives, but we wanted more of the robot vs. monster fighting. But that's for another review. It just makes me wonder whether del Toro teases us by giving us only small amounts of fantastical film, such as the monsters and creatures in Pan's Labrynth, so we stay in our seats to watch more and more and wait out the film to see if we do get more of that fantastical feel. But its del Toro's way of directing a film, and if he likes to tease an audience, so be it. We just need some of that teasing to actually turn into full on flirting.

   Pan's Labyrinth, by the way, is a 2006 fantasy drama Spanish film starring Ivana Baquero, Ariadna Gil, Sergi Lopez, and Doug Jones. Ivana Baquero plays Ofelia, a girl who's mother (Ariadna Gil) has married a an army captain (Sergi Lopez) and moves into the mountains with her daughter to give birth to her son while her husband works there. At the same time, guerrilla armies are camping up in these mountains, ready to kill any Spanish soldiers they can. A labyrinth lies near the cottage Ofelia and her mother are staying in, and Ofelia goes inside to discover a world she would've never thought to find. The guerrilla warfare really annoyed me in this movie. I thought the whole plot, to be honest, was cliche and generic. I'm not sure whether del Toro was going for the familiar "fairy tale" feel, but all I felt was the this-feels-like-its-already-been-done one. The guerrilla fighters were unnecessary to the plot, and it was just added in to create danger. We didn't know why they were fighting, all we knew was that their side lost the war and that they are the last of these soldiers. There was a nostalgic vibe coming from this film, taking you back to the days when you were listening to these kinds of stories in your bed before you fell asleep. Sadly, though, the rest of the film just felt very generic. The acting was solid in this movie, nothing really special coming from any of them. But the one exception was Doug Jones, the man who played the faun and the pale man (you will understand who he is when you watch the film). He totally takes this movie, engrossing himself into these characters and fully acting out. The faun was creepy when you first saw him, but he slowly turned out to be a wondrous sight, something I looked forward to watching, something I trusted and adored. The pale man was also very creepy and the way Doug Jones portrayed him was excellent and horrifying to see. Doug Jones is a great creature actor, high up there with ranks of those such as Andy Serkis and Jim Carrey.

   All in all, I did like Pan's Labyrinth. Sure, it wasn't the fantastical extravaganza I expected, but I liked that; it was something I didn't expect. Guillermo del Toro directs an excellent fairy tale for adults, one with horrors and violence, language gore, but still keeps that nostalgic, full "bedtime story" kind of feel to it. Pan's Labyrinth has grown on me since I've been writing this film, but I still wished it had more fantastical scenes rather than building on human development type scenes. Pan's Labyrinth is a one of kind film, but that doesn't mean it doesn't have that generic feel to it. In the end, I enjoyed Pan's Labyrinth, but wished I could've enjoyed it more, wish it could've changed a bit. But in all truth and honesty, which fairy tales really do change? If they did, there would be no point in them. 7/10.

So after I saw The Lone Ranger with my friend Blaine, he realized that I didn't see this film all the way yet. So he decided to fix that by showing me the film and now here's my review for Pan's Labyrinth.

Plot: Set in post- Civil War in Spain, Ofelia is a young girl who travels with her pregnant mother to meet her stepfather, Captain Vidal. During her stay she comes across a fairy who takes her deep into the labyrinth where she meets a fawn. He tells her that he believes that she is actually Princess Moanna of the underworld, who lost her memory due to going to the human world out of curiosity and eventually died. The father of the princess believes that her spirit would return, and so believing that Ofelia is Moanna, send her to these three quests before the full moon so that her essence may stay intact.

This was an excellent movie to finally see after hearing so much about it. It has a very sad, and dark story that has all these kinds of symbolism/similarities to other fairy tales and fantasy stories like Red Riding Hood and Alice in Wonderland. But what makes it really unique is how they put all the similarities together to make this story that is different. There are some things that you think will happen, but they might do something else entirely which makes it more original. The actors gave terrific performances, the most memorable would be Ivana Baquero, Sergi López and Doug Jones as Ofelia, Captain Vidal and The Fawn. And this movie is also known for having great cinematography, make up and art direction. And why not? All three of them are great. This film has great shots, the design is very creative, and I just really like how much work they really put into the makeup above everything else. Blaine showed me the special features for this film and that just impressed me all the more with why they deserved the Oscar for that particular category. They did an awful lot to bring a character to life or make a certain cut or wound look very real. And the process that they went through for creating the Fawn and the Pale Man and make them look very creative and unique to creating those certain types of creatures.

And that's my review for Pan's Labyrinth. It's a great movie with a very well written story, excellent acting, and as it's more commonly known, shows a great sense of art with its cinematography, art design and makeup. It's a very enjoyable film despite how particularly sad and dark it can be, but if you haven't seen this movie before, you should check it out.

Pan's Labyrinth, regarded by many as Guillermo del Toro's masterpiece and arguably regarded as one of the best films of the decade. I have seen this film twice and I never could grasp the power that everyone seems to receive from watching this film, but I am able to clutch on to a few things that this film does right.

The film is an original screenplay written by Guillermo del Toro, he mostly participates in the film's writing when he directs a film, and what he has crafted here is definitely something that is personal to him. Del Toro has written a story set in a time where the land of Spain was in a state of war within itself; the characters in this story, particularly the protagonist Ofelia, is searching for a land in order to gain peace and wipe away the horrors of reality. The film was able to establish the connection that Ofelia has with this magical world at the start, allowing us to believe and understand the connection she has with this fantasy. The tasks that Ofelia must go through seem to represent subtly a virtue that she must gain in order to become a better person, or for her sake a 'princess', which is important to have in a world that she currently lives in and the world she aspires to join in. Del Toro lets the audience follow two storylines, Ofelia's and the Spanish rebels, in a way they both connect but each one can be made into a film of it's own. The characters in this film are great to watch, with Ofelia being so driven in her goal to find her way back home and Vidal being so ruthless that my eyes widen whenever he has plans to inflict pain. The faun was interesting to see as he is a creature that is, to my knowledge, never been seen in cinema. The dialogue in this film, for the most part, works but there are a few times where it needed a little more substance but this is just a minor issue.

This film, is my starting point in del Toro's filmography. Pan's Labyrinth is a film that contains Fantasy elements that have been found on films like Alice In Wonderland and The Wizard of Oz but employs a much darker tone. Del Toro made this film to feel accessible to adults as he doesn't allow the story to be sugar coated in order to sell Ofelia's story. Del Toro has been known to incorporate horror in his films, and he does so here but not just for the sake of having it. The horror comes from the pain that these characters suffer and it allows the audience to feel their pain, regardless of who is the victim. It is supported by not holding back on the use of blood and violence, allowing the film to create a stronger effect on us. The film's pacing works, especially towards the climax, as he cuts back and forth to the war in reality and Ofelia's journey. My main issue with the film is that the film leans towards more on the reality side, with the fantasy aspect of it feeling underwhelming and unexplored. I wanted more from this magical world in order for me to care in Ofelia succeeding, it doesn't have to go to such lengths in dedicating a long scene for it to be explored but it could have been included in the dialogue between the faun and Ofelia.

The film's cinematography was handled by Guillermo Navarro, who is a frequent collaborator with del Toro. The earliest film I have seen of Navarro's work is Jackie Brown, which was darker than Quentin Tarantino's previous films; that style in creating that dark atmosphere is found here. Navarro's photography is one of the main reasons why del Toro's film feels very mature. This allows us to take the film's story seriously and understand that this is more than just a children's fantasy film. Never throughout the film does it look natural. Navarro handles the film's night/dark scenes to look cold with a blue palette, while he exhibits the daytime sequences to feel very warm. The camera captures what it needs to establish the scene and support the ideas that del Toro wants the scenes to project. I hope this collaboration keeps on going in future films as both seem to have a great understanding of each other's intentions. 

The film's score was handled by Javier Navarrete who has worked with del Toro previously on The Devil's Backbone and Cronos. His score here doesn't draw attention to itself, but rather subtly emerges in order to sell a scene or to avoid the scene from feeling still. The only time when Navarrete's score stands out is when it uses the lullaby in the film, as it stays with you throughout and even when it ends. The score didn't sound too melodramatic or did it feel too cliche'd but it definitely didn't show that it was a force to be reckon with.

Ivana Baquero plays the film's protagonist. She played the part well but it never got to a point where I was amazed or inspired by her work, Baquero just performed what was required in order to come off as tolerable. Sergi Lopez on the other hand was a standout, maybe it also is due to how well written his role is. Lopez succeeds to come off as ruthless and threatening without having to be so obvious to us on how 'evil' this guy really is. Which is the reason why his moments of violence comes off as a shock rather than just something that is expected. Maribel Verdu did her part well as Mercedes. She was able to play off as an 'inside man' character while also be a caring older sister for Ofelia. Doug Jones as Pan (Faun) was a delight to watch as he was able to project himself as someone who is bizarre but also frightening.

My opinion of Pan's Labyrinth may be in the minority but I cannot say that this film is not worth a watch as it has the ability to create a bridge between reality and fantasy and coming off it satisfied with what Guillermo del Toro has crafted for us.

Peerlessly enchanting. Every aspect of this genre-blending gothic horror folk tale is executed superbly. Fantastic creatures and otherworldly hope contrast impactfully against the ugliness of tyranny and mortality. Gorgeously filmed, lush in its color scheme and setting, and absolutely unforgettable. While I wouldn't exactly call it Alice in Wonderland by any means, Pan's Labyrinth opens up an unexplored visual narrative, adult fantasy period-piece horror. Overall the visuals are frightening enough to build the stakes of the characters and the story develops on a basic story arch that's both common but original with it's own blend of realism and fantasy.

Del Toro's film is an uneasy blend of fantasy and violence (including some sadistic violence), using that old plot chestnut that posits an escape into fantasy as a reaction to trauma (e.g., The Neverending Story).  Although presenting a pre-adolescent girl as the central protagonist suggests a film for kids (as does some of the cuter digital imagery), the violence is too extreme.  Del Toro isn't just enamored with style (as Tim Burton now seems to be) but aims for an underlying psychological truth (shopworn though it may be).  Setting the film just after the Spanish Civil War also allows him to take advantage of the spookier feel of period costumes and settings.  Above all, the phantasmagorical creatures (encountered during the "tasks" that the young girl must complete to achieve her entry to the underworld) make this worth watching.

Incredible aurora of fantasy, horror and drama that is set in a historical time period. The movie takes place shortly after the Spanish Civil War. A girl and her mother set to live with her new husband, a sadistic captain in the Spanish Army. She discovers a stone labyrinth where she comes across a faun. The faun claims she is the legendary princess foretold in a legendary story. To prove she is the chosen one she must accomplish three tasks before the next full moon. I like to think of this film as a graphic fairy tale not for the pre teens. The movie is in Spanish with English subtitles, but it's not bothersome as you'll be paying too much attention to the beautiful set pieces, inventive characters and the vast lighting and composition its cinematography has to offer. This is one of the most technically accomplished films I've seen. Guillermo del Tero who wrote and directed this film has created something very unique and adventurous that keeps you on your feet and unleash your emotions as to what is going on in the film whether its the girl stuck in a dead end during her quests or drawing anger at the cruel punishment her stepfather brings to his people. del Toro has cemented his place among the best filmmakers of today. Everyone who is into fantasy stories such as Lord of the Rings, Harry Potter, etc. will really enjoy this movie. Pan's Labyrinth is one of the few masterpieces to come out in the last ten years. And it will continue to be a masterpiece as time moves on.

Despite being quite a prominent name in cinema just now, director Guillermo del Toro hasn't actually made that many movies. He came to attention in 1993 with his excellent feature debut "Cronos" before Hollywood quickly took note and employed him on such films as "Mimic" and "Blade II". However, his strengths lie in his own original work where he retains creative control. Of which, there are three that really stand out; the aforementioned "Cronos" is one, "The Devil's Backbone" another and "Pan's Labyrinth" - which to this day, remains his masterpiece. 
 Following the Spanish Civil War in 1944, young Ofelia (Baquero) moves to a rural town with her pregnant mother (Gil) to live with her Fascist military stepfather (LÃ³pez) who is determined to weed out resistance fighters to Franco's dictatorship. It's in this remote town that Ofelia meets a faun in the centre of a labyrinth who tells her that she is a princess. However, to claim her rightful place in this magical land she must perform certain gruesome tasks to prove her royalty.
 It's hard to pigeon hole a film like Pan's Labyrinth as there are so many facets to it's structure. On the one hand, it's a political/historical drama and on the other it's a fantasy/horror. Few (if any) films will spring to mind when these genres are mentioned in the same breath which reflects the very craftsmanship that's at work here. One thing that you can undoubtedly count on, though, is it's highly imaginative nature. Sure, we've had fantastical stories before where a young girl escapes her constrained life to enter bigger and more possible worlds. We've also had commentaries on the brutalities and restrictions of fascist regimes but to combine them into a wondrous journey of life, struggle and imagination is an amalgamation that I have rarely witnessed. Such is the case with this film and such is the skill of del Toro in his writing and  handling of the material. He incorporates an abundance of childhood fantasies, from delving into books and mythology - that feature fauns and fairies - to the power of a piece of chalk on the wall. This may be built around the point of view of a child's eye but its also not afraid to explore the darker recesses of that very imagination and construct some of the most monstrous creatures that can inhabit that realm. Del Toro is in absolute command here and he's aided, immeasurably, by cinematographer Guillermo Navarro in capturing and contrasting his world within a world; one is a visually striking and enchanting fantasia, the other a stark and brutal reality. It's a balance that's difficult to achieve but with deft handling of coexisting genres, del Toro's vision is able to come to fruition and manages to be both a reminder of the rigidity of fascism and the escapable ability of an imaginary youthful mind.
 To embody the young protagonist, we are gifted an outstanding performance from Ivana Baquero who carries a heavy weight on her young shoulders and does so, with a skill beyond her years. Sergi Lopez also provides marvellous support as  the bestial Captain Vidal who's a smouldering villain that's on a par with any of the war genre's nastiest characters.
 It's very difficult to find criticism in this film as there simply, isn't any. The only one that stands is in the film's title. It's slightly misleading as "Pan" never actually features here. The original international title translates as "Labyrinth of the Fuan" which is probably the most pedantic gripe you'll ever hear from me.
 A stunning piece of work that's both beautifully and horrifically executed. Modern masterpiece is a term that gets brandished around too often these days but this is one that's certainly deserving of such praise.

Pan's Labyrinth is Ofelia's attempt to escape the cruelty of the world she is forced to live in. Pan's Labyrinth uses various mythical situations to depict how Ofelia is making sense of everything happening around her. With a vague understanding of the world, and an acute understanding of fairy tales, Ofelia combines the two and what comes out of this is an dark dream that no young child shall live through. Like the revolutionists around, Ofelia understands the importance of sacrificing and protecting what is innocent, and what grew out of this resistance was a chance for new life to grow. Guillerme del Toro creates a beautifully crafted story based in a wondrous world, and is not afraid to cross traditional boundaries, which is definitely applaudable. The main gripe I had with the film was a feeling of stagnation at various points, that I really felt like it needed some sort of propellent to get it going again.

This was definitely not what I was expecting, but it was beautifully done and a really good story.

Boyfriend said I would really like this movie being a "history nerd" and all. Also its a thought provoking movie, which is a bonus always. First of all...he was right. I did like this movie. ^.^

There was so many things going on at once during this movie. The poor rebels trying to fight against Pedro and his "sadistic" ways, Pedro and his wife struggling with her being sickly and about to give birth, and then Ofelia's fantasy world which has its own drama unfolding. I loved how well everything blended into each other and how well things played off each other. 

I loved the costumes and it seemed very authentic. I also must extend some kuddos to the screen writers for it was some good writing. The dialogue was excellent and the acting added to it. Even the little actress who played Ofelia did wonderful (you know child actors tend to be cheesy sometimes). We had to read the subtitles, because the dialogue was in Spanish, but that was okay...it seemed to be better in Spanish and it added to the feel of the movie. 

Even though this was a really good movie, it was really sad. :/ I teared up a couple times throughout the film. Along with that...I hated the ending. I can't say much without ruining it, but it was rather sad and it made me mad. Stupid ending >.>. I see the symbolism behind it, but still I was not happy. Don't get me wrong it wasn't a BAD ending or anything, but it upset me and mad me cry. Oh well, I guess. But it did lead to a good conversation and debate on whether or not Ofelia's "fantasy" was a fantasy or not. Was her world real or was it just the imagination of a lonely child in a dark world. Personally...I think it was real in a way. I'll have to re-watch it and look deeper into it.

In the end, this was a good movie. It's also a good date movie *wink wink*. It was a sad movie, but it was good and thought provoking. The acting, the screenwriting, the costumes, and the plot was amazing. Make sure to watch it in its native language with subtitles, for it seemed to add to the movie. Overall I shall stamp this with 5 stars.

Guillermo Del Toro follows the same pattern of his previous horror movie, The Devil's Backbone, by combining two stories in one, but with a lot better result this time.

Superbly detailed fairy tale that takes place during a revolt in 1944 within Spain, separate from the events of World War II. The movie starts with the foreshadowing of poor young girl, named Ofelia (Ivano Baquero), is shown dying in a wooded area, adjacent to a lodge for which she was previously brought to by her pregnant mother (Ariadna Gil) and vicious, evil stepfather (Sergio Lopez), a captain of the offensive. While there, Ofelia wonders into the forest and daydreams, meeting a bizarre creature called "faun" (Doug Jones) who claims that she is the Princess Moanna and that she is the one who help him and other bizarre creatures, along with her pregnant mother, who becomes very, very ill. At the same time, Ofelia's vicious stepfather starts his kill into the forest and begins murdering those who he believes have betrayed him and Spain, including dictator De Franco (who presided over Spain for more than thirty years).

Exceptionally grim but devastating and stunning piece of work that will leave anyone haunted for days. The performances of Baquero and Lopez are unforgettable, as well as Meribel Verdu, the wonderful and helpful housekeeper whose brother is trying to takedown the captain and his crew. Really sad and oppressive, but the films works on an extraordinary level. There is a very good chance that this film will leave you in tears. Notably and understandably, not a kids movie by any means!

I loved this film. I did have to watch it a couple of times to fully grasp it.

Acclaimed director Guillermo del Toro ("Hellboy", "The Devil's Backbone"), creates one of the most exciting and visually stunning adult-themed fables ever. "Pan's Labyrinth" is one of the cinema's great fantasies--rich with darkness and wonder. It's a fairy tale of such potency and grandeur, that it reconnects the adult imagination to our primal thrill, and horror stories that held us spellbound as children. As gruesome and brutal as it is enchanting and spellbinding--"Pan's Labyrinth" is a movie intended for adults. It is a harsh, uncompromising film--but equally just as beautiful and moving."Pan's Labyrinth" is itself a narrative maze, with multiple stories that branch apart and back together again. 

This dark fairy tale plays out against the backdrop of Spain in 1944. A monstrous Fascist captain (López) is determined to flush out soldiers of the resistance, as his pregnant wife arrives at his countryside headquarters with her young daughter. The young girl Ofelia (Baquero), escapes the brutality of her new environment by drifting into a fantasy world where she comes across a mysterious faun. The faun tells her that she is a princess from a kingdom in the underground. The faun also tells that her that her father is waiting for her, but she needs to accomplish three challenging and dangerous assignments first. 
Ofelia's challenges do not arise like arbitrary plot obstacles--they are organic to her (and the movie's) development. She learns not only to follow instructions--and that there are heavy prices to pay for failing to abide by them. But also to trust her own instincts about what is right and wrong. In order to find her true self, she must also find the her inner-strength to break the rules imposed by authority. An individual conscience. What could be a more powerful anti-fascist weapon than that?

In a dark, harsh, and violent world, Ofelia lives in her magical world trying to survive her tasks and see her father again. Soon, the line between fantasy and reality begins to blur, and before Ofelia can turn back, she finds herself at the center of the ferocious battle between Good and Evil. Incredibly unique fable that blends fantasy and fearsome violence, ultimately merging the two stories together. Superbly realized--a rare film that invites repeated viewings to fully absorb all that writer-director del Toro has put into it. Oscar winner for Cinematography, Makeup, and Art Direction.

What a brilliant movie, most definitely not for the faint hearted as it shows the absolute violence of a war crazed father figure and the innocence of a child who has to deal with that rejection!! she creates a beautiful (but scary/strange) world to take her mind off of her circumstances - which most adults does to a certain extend!!! a must see!!!

Del Toro's masterpiece Pan's Labyrinth is a rather grounded adult fairy tale. It's apparent that the film was crafted with a distinct vision and intense care. Interesting characters, unique world, beautiful effects, and wonderful themes Pan's Labyrinth is absolutely the best in it's class.

The film captures the theme of escapism faultlessly, switching between reality and fantasy with smooth transitions and leaving the audience wondering what is real and what isn't. The harsh reality that is Ofelia's life with the sadistic army officer Captain Vidal is beautifully balanced with the equally dark but vastly more enjoyable fantasy land she creates. Ivana Baquero, who was only 12 when the film was made is an incredible child actor who was able to portray such extreme emotions for someone so young. You really believed she was upset/scared/furious at all the appropriate moments and she led the audience on her journey very naturally.

It's completely warranted that the film won 3 Oscars for it's visual elements (Art Direction, Cinematography and Makeup) because it was truly a treat to watch. The creatures were straight out of a vivid imagination and they moved and spoke as characters rather than just people in funny costume.

And finally, I'm a big lover of horror and gore and this film incorporated that in moments that took me completely by surprise. One moment I was in awe of the beautiful creatures and sets and the next someone was getting brutally beaten or killed. But it wasn't excessive and it was done so artistically that it really just added to the overall brilliance of the film. If you haven't seen it, do yourself a favour and rent it out. Yes, there are subtitles and they are a deterrent for some people but if you can overcome that you won't regret it.

This movie was unexpectedly good. It sneaks up on you. It brings the creepy factor of the true old fashioned Celtic fey realms (as opposed to Disney and Victorian flower fairies) into the forefront without losing its magical quality. It includes all the classic requirements of a good otherworld story - mysterious and questionable connections, odd quests for great purposes, tests of morality and honesty, things never being what they seem, real magic as opposed to sparkles and fire balls, mentors you aren't sure you can trust.  Because you never really know if you can trust a fairy til the end in a good fairy story.  It also isn't shy about the fact the otherworld - while itself not portrayed as a place of perfection - is literally an escape for this girl from a horrific reality on our human side of things.  A reality which is also not afforded any less development than it deserves - there are no magical girl comicbook storylines of flitting off to an otherworld while nothing goes on back at home and no one's wondering where you are in this film.  If anyone who watches this has had real experience with fairies it will hit close to home, and as not everyone has the sight you'll feel for the girl and all the audience members who assume she's crazy when you realize she's the only who can see her fey friends.

One of the best movies I've ever seen.
'Pan's Labyrinth' is a wonderfully twisted tale filled with immense imagination but laden with one-dimensional characters and a predictable plot.

This fantastic film wouldn't be half as good had it been in English.  There truly is something about the Spanish language that makes it all the more beautiful.  The sharp contrast between the world of the imagined and the harsh reality fits perfectly.  Some parts are very difficult to watch, as the brutatlity is quite extreme, but it truly is one of the most imaginative films I have ever seen.

Unique, very well crafted adult fairy tale.  The fantasy component, while not getting much screen time, is effective at conveying an interesting twist in the genre.  Performances across the board are effective and at times powerful. 

Granted, Pan's Labyrinth is fairly bizarre but is more than approachable.  It is a spellbinding tale of love, sacrifice, and courage that is incredibly memorable.  If you are looking for something unique and a little different, look no further than this classic.
